facts.text: The Amazon rainforest is often called the 'lungs of the Earth' because it produces about 6-9% of the world's oxygen, not 20%.
Wind turbines can reach over 200 meters tall—taller than the Statue of Liberty!
The amount of solar energy that reaches Earth in one hour could power the world for a year.
Cows produce methane, a greenhouse gas over 25 times more potent than CO₂.
Antarctica holds about 60% of the world’s fresh water, mostly locked in ice.
The Earth’s oceans absorb about 25% of human-made CO₂ emissions.
Only about 9% of all plastic ever produced has been recycled.
If food waste were a country, it would be the third-largest emitter of greenhouse gases.
Lightning strikes the Earth over 8 million times a day.
The Sahara Desert was once a lush, green savanna thousands of years ago.
Earth is the only planet in our Solar System not named after a god.
A single tree can absorb up to 22 kilograms (48 pounds) of CO₂ per year.
The Great Barrier Reef is the world’s largest living structure and can be seen from space.
LED bulbs use at least 75% less energy than traditional incandescent bulbs.
The hottest temperature ever recorded on Earth was 56.7°C (134°F) in Death Valley, USA.
The blue whale is the largest animal to have ever lived on Earth.
The Earth’s core is about as hot as the surface of the sun, around 5,500°C (9,932°F).
Plastic bags can take up to 1,000 years to decompose.
About 71% of the Earth’s surface is covered by water.
A group of flamingos is called a 'flamboyance'.
Earth’s atmosphere is about 78% nitrogen and 21% oxygen.
The first Earth Day was celebrated in 1970.
Antarctica is the world’s largest desert, not the Sahara.
Solar panels generate electricity even on cloudy days, though less efficiently.
Oceans produce at least 50% of the planet’s oxygen, mainly from phytoplankton.
The deepest point in the ocean is the Mariana Trench, about 11,000 meters (36,000 feet) deep.
The average person generates over 4 pounds (1.8 kg) of trash every day.
Bees are responsible for pollinating about one-third of the food we eat.
The largest living organism is a fungus (Armillaria ostoyae) in Oregon, covering over 3.5 square miles.
About 1 million seabirds and 100,000 marine mammals die from plastic pollution every year.
Electric cars produce zero tailpipe emissions.
Composting helps reduce landfill waste and creates nutrient-rich soil.
The ozone layer helps protect Earth from harmful ultraviolet (UV) rays.
A single wind turbine can power up to 1,500 homes.
Mangrove forests protect coastlines from erosion and storms.
Earth’s gravity is slightly weaker at the equator than at the poles.
The oldest known tree is a bristlecone pine in California, over 4,850 years old.
Paper can be recycled up to 7 times before the fibers become too short.
The first windmills were used in Persia (modern Iran) around 500–900 AD.
A lightning bolt is about five times hotter than the surface of the sun.
Earth is not a perfect sphere; it’s slightly flattened at the poles.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all landmasses combined.
Coral reefs support about 25% of all marine life.
Bamboo can grow up to 91 cm (3 feet) in a single day.
Mauna Loa in Hawaii is the world’s largest active volcano.
Underwater earthquakes can cause tsunamis in oceans.
Some frogs, like the wood frog, can freeze solid and survive the winter.
The first electric car was built in the 19th century.
The Earth travels around the Sun at about 107,000 km/h (67,000 mph).
A hummingbird’s heart can beat up to 1,260 times per minute.
Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to run a TV for three hours.
Earth’s atmosphere extends about 10,000 km (6,200 miles) into space.
The largest waterfall on Earth is underwater, in the Denmark Strait.
The world’s largest solar farm is Bhadla Solar Park in India.
Polar bears have black skin under their white fur to absorb heat.
The Mid-Ocean Ridge is the world’s longest mountain range, mostly underwater.
A group of crows is called a 'murder'.
Earth’s magnetic field protects us from harmful solar radiation.
The largest living thing is a fungus (Armillaria) in Oregon.
Air pollution causes more deaths each year than car accidents.
The Sahara Desert expands by about 48 kilometers (30 miles) every year.
Algae in oceans produce more oxygen than all the trees on land.
Earthquakes are measured using the Richter scale.
The tallest tree is a coast redwood in California, over 115 meters (380 feet) tall.
The world’s largest ice sheet is in Antarctica.
Some turtles can breathe through their butts—a process called cloacal respiration.
Earth is about 4.54 billion years old.
The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is estimated to be twice the size of Texas.
A single plastic straw can take up to 200 years to decompose.
The Dead Sea is the lowest point on Earth's surface, about 430 meters (1,410 feet) below sea level.
The world’s smallest mammal is the bumblebee bat.
The Sun is the largest energy source for Earth.
A cloud can weigh more than a million pounds.
Some Greenland sharks can live to be over 400 years old.
Yellowstone, established in 1872, was the first national park in the world.
The Earth’s crust is made up of tectonic plates that move and cause earthquakes.
The largest animal migration is the daily movement of zooplankton in the ocean.
Earth is the densest planet in the Solar System.
The driest place on Earth is the Atacama Desert in Chile.
A group of jellyfish is called a 'smack'.
Some mushrooms glow in the dark due to bioluminescence.
The Nile is the longest river in the world, stretching over 6,650 kilometers (4,130 miles).
The first wind turbines for electricity were built in the late 19th century.
Every ton of recycled paper saves about 17 trees.
The ostrich is the largest living bird on Earth.
The coldest temperature ever recorded was −89.2°C (−128.6°F) in Antarctica.
Sunflowers can remove toxins from soil—a process called phytoremediation.
The Sahara is the world’s largest hot desert, but Antarctica is the largest overall.
Venus is the hottest planet, but Earth is the only one with liquid water on its surface.
The mudskipper is a fish that can walk on land.
The Earth rotates once every 23 hours, 56 minutes, and 4 seconds.
About 80% of the world’s forests have been destroyed or degraded.
Sputnik, launched in 1957, was the first artificial satellite.
The Amazon is home to more species than any other place on Earth.
A group of owls is called a 'parliament'.
Earth is the third planet from the Sun.
Son Doong Cave in Vietnam is the world’s largest cave.
The average American uses about 82 gallons (310 liters) of water per day.
There are about three trillion trees on Earth—more than stars in the Milky Way.
The Three Gorges Dam in China is the world’s largest hydroelectric dam.
The Arctic is warming about twice as fast as the rest of the planet.
A group of porcupines is called a 'prickle'.
The first photograph of Earth from space was taken in 1946.
The Great Barrier Reef is the world’s largest coral reef system.
Lightning can strike the same place twice.
Earth’s circumference is about 40,075 kilometers (24,901 miles).
Oxygen is the most common element in the Earth's crust.
Some plants can 'hear' and respond to sound vibrations.
The Caspian Sea is the world’s largest lake.
A group of ferrets is called a 'business'.
The oldest known living animal was a clam named Ming, 507 years old.
The world’s largest hydroelectric plant is the Three Gorges Dam in China.
Grand Prismatic Spring in Yellowstone is Earth's largest hot spring.
Alessandro Volta invented the first battery in 1800.
Some deserts, like the Gobi, can be cold as well as dry.
Rafflesia arnoldii is the world’s largest flower.
The first solar-powered calculator was invented in the 1970s.
The blue whale is the largest animal on Earth and lives in the ocean.
